elements.text: [Part One]
Hubbub of crowd speaking French. Crash!
If you are not prepared to take back your words against the Queen, I will have to kill you.
Run me through, Delmarre, and fifty will step forward to take my place.
Fifty of the Cardinal's guards to one King's Musketeer? Ha, ha! Hardly a challenge, Morand. Besides, that's not the point, is it? The point is, you'd be dead. Ha!
Draws sword, brief fight.
Delmarre, put the boy down and come have a drink. It's your round.
Not until I've taught this dog some manners. Oh, I think his friend wants a word.
What?
Behind you.
Swords clash, someone cries out. Speech punctuated by blows.

It's never wise to creep up on a Musketeer. Especially one with the wit, guile, sartorial elegance and charming good looks of Frangois Rouffet. (fight over.) I'll put that bottle on your tab, shall I?

I must have misheard when you said Queen Anne is nothing more than a common whore who consorts with the Duke of Buckingham. Surely, Captain Morand, you said I may be in the service of Cardinal Richelieu, but my loyalty to the honour of Queen Anne is unswerving. (punch) Then again. (punch)
Bravo, but your dog is still awake.
Well, hurry up and finish him. At this rate, the landlord may run out of wine.
Oh, very well. I say, isn't that the Cardinal running naked through the street?
What? Oh! (thud)

Captain, Captain, I appear to have left my purse in my other cloak. And as my friend has pointed out, it is my round. Now, as your purse is far too full, I shall take twenty pistoles for your ignorance, and twenty more as a lesson in good manners. The Cardinal pays his captains too well, it seems.
Landlord, more wine.
(chuckles) The Cardinal pays fat wages these days. Perhaps we should ask for a transfer?
The red velvet would clash with my Delmarre, look out!
Punch!
For God's sake. The Captain still has fight in him. Look at that. My best cloak, ruined.
Come now sir, I implore you. Make your move. Strike now or I shall perish from boredom. And I'm sure we both agree that is no way for a warrior to meet his maker.
Your impatience is second only to your insolence. In battle, one must savour the
sweet taste of victory.
Tell that to the General who lies bloody on the battlefield with a knife in his back.
Insolence does not become you. Prepare to suffer the consequences of your babbling. Check.
Your Majesty, if we concentrated on playing rather than talking, we would finish in half the time.
Indulge me, Richelieu.
Very well. Knight takes Bishop. It would appear my life is in your hands.
(laughs) The Crown wipes away the Church.
A brave but foolish move. A pawn stands ready, unnoticed in the shadows, waiting to strike. Ha! The Knight is lost.
Your confidence is unfounded. If the Rook should move here
The Crown will fall. I believe the phrase I'm looking for is checkmate.
Damn you, Richelieu.
Your Majesty, it's just a game.
(sighs) Everything's just a game to you, Cardinal.

Can we talk about this sensibly, sentient lifeform to sentient lifeform? If this is going to work, you and I are going to have to have some kind of arrangement, aren't we? Now look, I need to get to the navigational controls which are underneath you, so (cat meows) if I could (slash! hiss!) Ow! On the other hand, I'm sure I could probably reprogramme them from the other side of the console. K9, where are you when I really need you.
Internal door opens. Giggling girls enter.
Ah, Pharaoh, all set? I hope the wardrobe room had everything you needed?
Please, Doctor, I no longer need that title. And, as you can see, I have shed the last vestige of my own time.
Even your hair's growing. You could join the army with a cut like that.
Yes, well, charming. Absolutely charming. Well done, Peri.
Maybe I should dump botany and take up fashion. I think I've missed my calling. Want some tips, Doctor?
Er, no. I'm perfectly happy with this, thank you. I could probably do with a new stick of celery, though.
(laughs) You are the strangest man I have ever met.
Hmm. It's a hobby.
Your Tardis is truly wondrous, Doctor.
Doctor, couldn't Erimem stay? Just for a while. It would be so cool, travelling with a real live Pharaoh.
I am no longer Pharaoh, Peri.
Cool? I'm sorry, it's out of the question, Erimem. I really shouldn't have taken you away from Egypt in the first place.
You have been more than kind, both of you. I can ask no more. You saved my life.
Besides, I think you'll be much happier where we're going. Ah, we're landing.
In the right place, I hope.
A little faith, please, Peri.
Why do you make fun of the Doctor?
(laughs) You've got a lot to learn, Erimem. Aren't you going to check the coordinates?
No need. I know exactly where we are. The Braxiatel Collection, planetoid KS159. If we're lucky, we should be just in time for dinner.
Tardis door opens.
Oh, no.
Where is he?
What is a beautiful lady such as yourself doing in a place like this?
It would appear that I am waiting for my beloved, who is late.

For which, my dear, I apologise. My work is taking longer than I thought. That plus this wretched damp air has given me a head cold. I wouldn't keep the beautiful Madame de Chevreuse waiting for the entire kingdom. Now here, take this.
A letter? For her.
Now, now, my dear. You know that you are still my favourite. No one could replace you. But this is necessary.
For the cause?
Indeed. For the cause.
It's always for the cause.
But soon this will all be over and my only cause will be you.
And we can be together, my love, without having to hide in the shadows?
Of course. I shall be proud to display you on my arm. But for now, you have a task ahead of you.
It's only for you that I do this, my Duke. But it must be the last time, do you hear?
It will be, I promise.
I must fly, then. Take care, my love.
And you.
Footsteps recede.
Women. The world is full of women, all of them wretched.
Another game?
I would, Sire, but I don't want to miss my cocoa.
Running away like one of your guards, Richelieu?
Must we get into this debates about the merits of our personal guards yet again? Can't we talk about the drains instead?
Afraid that you may have to concede that my Musketeers are the noblest breed of soldier in all of France?
A noble breed of layabouts and gigolos. How many more reports must I read of skirmishes on the streets? Twelve in the last week alone. You outlaw duelling and they ignore you.
Door opens.
Now what?
Your Majesty, Eminence, Musketeers Delmarre and Rouffet, and Guard Captain Morand.
Ah, messengers from the angels to prove my point.
Oh, very well. Have them enter.
Yes, your Majesty.
(sotto) Stop being such a woman. It's a scratch.
(sotto) Yes, yes, I know it is, you idiot.
Door closes. Footsteps
(sotto) The surgeon tied the bandage too tight, that's all. Anyway, you were supposed to be watching my back.
(sotto) I can hardly miss it with the weight you've put on.
Gentlemen, I hope you have a good reason to interrupt the important state business of myself and Cardinal Richelieu.
Oh please don't feel you need one.
I thought I must come immediately to report the action of these miscreants in their unprovoked attack upon your own guards, Eminence.
Unprovoked! Why, you
Draws sword.
Rouffet!
A duel in the throne room. How delightful.
Sheath, gentlemen. Thank you. Would somebody please explain what's going on?
Morand?
Morand clears his throat, steps forward and reads.
Whilst drinking in the Crown's Courage ale house with Guard Lieutenant Ferraud. You remember him, Eminence. I trained him with my own hands. Unswerving in his loyalty. He was like a son to me.
Spare us the tribute, Morand.
Yes, of course. We came across Musketeers Delmarre and Rouffet engaged in activities of a sordid nature.
We were having our breakfast.

On seeing the Lieutenant and myself, they set upon us without provocation, killing Ferraud in the process. He bled to death in my arms, Eminence, struck down in the prime of his life by these thugs, his youthful energy ebbing away.

Morand, if you don't shut up, I'll have you ebbed away. Your Majesty, even you must see that these men's actions prove their guilt. It strikes me that hours away from the most important social event in the Court's calendar, an event you yourself have claimed will unite this proud nation of ours, it is sad that we, or indeed you, need protection from your own guards. These men must be punished, severely.
I'll be the judge of that, Cardinal. Well, what have you two got to say for yourselves?
He's lying, your Majesty. They publicly attacked the honour of the Queen. We had to act to defend her.
There you have it. The matter is settled, Cardinal.
You're prepared to take their word without a full investigation into the incident?
They're my best men, Cardinal. I trust them. You should do the same. Now, don't you have some money to steal from the poor? Run along now.
As I'm sure you have an innocent stag to hunt down in the woods. Morand, attend me.
Eminence.
Door opens and closes.
Bravo, gentlemen. Did you see the look on his face?
Er, yes, Sire.
That'll teach him to blacken the name of my Musketeers. (laughs) For that, my friends, take a sovereign each and celebrate!
Your Majesty, we couldn't.
I insist. Now, be off with you. I have a ball to prepare for, and I shall expect both of you to be in attendance. And Delmarre, get my personal physician to look at that wound.
Thank you, Sire. Our compliments to the Queen.
Footsteps, door opens and closes.
I'll be sure to tell her when she bothers to return home.

Not exactly what I had in mind. Want to talk about it, old girl? Why seventeenth century France? Oh, I see. You want our guest to stay. Hmm. If I didn't know better, I'd say Peri had put you up to this.
Door opens.
Who are you talking to, Doctor?
Er
Ah, he does it all the time.
Door closes. Street sounds.
It's quite sweet, really.
Yes, well.
The girls laugh.
Is this really another time?
Yes. And place. Paris, 1626 to be exact. A good few centuries after your time.
It's beyond anything I could have imagined.
You never get used to it. I get goosebumps every time I step out somewhere new. (deep breath) Yuck. Some places smell better than others, though.
Sewage systems weren't as advanced in this period, Peri, compared to what you're used to.
Is it safe to look around?
You should be all right, now that you two have changed, and besides
Besides what?
It would be rude not to.
What a way to work up an appetite. Kill a Cardinal's guard and insult a religious leader.
Huh, you've always got an appetite, Rouffet. Now, where shall we eat? Planchet's?
Where else? I wonder how much wine a sovereign will buy? Delmarre, look. Isn't that Madame de Chevreuse? We've not seen her at Court for months.
I hadn't noticed.
You're not still pining for her? For heaven's sake, you're not the first. I doubt you'll be the last. Even Morand has seen the inside of her boudoir.
For someone who asks so many questions, you learn very little.
I
Let's eat. At least when you're stuffing your face I can't hear your voice.
In this period of history, France was undergoing a great deal of social upheaval. Cardinal Richelieu had a vision for uniting the cultural and
Richelieu? Wasn't he the bad guy?
Oh, no, no, no, no, no. Quite the opposite. Alexandre Dumas has a lot to answer for. Tiresome man. Completely ignored the notes I gave him on his first draft.
Hey, where's Erimem?
Hmm. Ah, I think our friend is making some new discoveries.
Amazing.
What is?
Knocking.
It's incredible. I've never seen anything like it. Why would somebody put glass where a window should be?
Ah. But when is a window not a window? When it's a jar. Well, I thought it was funny.
This place is like nothing I have ever seen.
Come on, you two. Hungry?
I could eat a horse.
I wouldn't say that too loudly around here. You may get exactly what you ask for. I thought you were vegetarian?
Urgh. I'd much rather eat boar.
We're in the food capital of Europe. I think we can find something a little more adventurous than what you were used to in Thebes. This way.
Bump.
Oh!
You're
Oh, I'm so sorry. Let me help you.
Please forgive me. (runs off) I, I didn't
Hey, come back. I was only helping
They were frightened of you. How very odd.
It's weird. Since we arrived, I've had this feeling that everyone's watching me, but when I look round, they look away.
I was used to that from my people. And you are very attractive, Peri.
Oh, thanks.

Hmm. It's interesting, but I really wouldn't worry. Now, perhaps after lunch we should take a stroll down to the Louvre. Of course, it won't become a museum until 1793 and the King is still in residence, but it is the most beautiful building.
Doctor

Did I ever tell you I was there when King Philippe Auguste laid the cornerstone to the original back in oh, must have been the twelfth century. I didn't have the heart to tell him that one day it would be desecrated with a giant glass pyramid.
Pyramid?
Guys, I'm finding all this fascinating, but er, do you mind if I strike out on my own for a bit? I think you've got more than a willing pupil in Erimem.
Er, I don't know. I could be dangerous.
Doctor, after everything we've been through, I think I can handle a morning stroll.
Hmm. Well, all right. But don't go too far. We'll be just over there.
Doctor, this is Paris. What could possibly go wrong?
In a carriage.
Morand, I charge you with keeping peace on the streets, and all you can do is get one of your men killed. Remind me, why do I pay you?
Eminence
No, no, don't bother. I've already got a headache. While the King continues to arrange tedious social engagements and argue with the Queen, my work will be incomplete. Something must be done.
Your men will do whatever you command, Eminence
They'd better. The sooner we can. Wait. Driver, stop!
[OC]: Whoa.
Eminence? Isn't that?
I'm not blind. What is that stupid girl doing alone on the streets? Morand, take two men and follow her, then report straight back to me.
Eminence.
Carriage door opens.
[OC]: You men, with me.
Carriage door closed.
So, my dear. Perhaps we will finally learn the truth. (bangs on roof) Drive on!
Your Majesty. Your Majesty?
: Can I help?
(gasps) Oh Majesty. Your Majesty, you startled me. My heart is racing in my bosom.
Hmm. So I see. My apologies, but I too am surprised to find anyone here. After all, these are the Queen's private gardens.
In that case, Sire, are we both making an indiscretion?
I was taking some air. The palace is in chaos, what with the preparations for tonight's ball. I was just remembering what it was like when these gardens were filled with the Queen's laughter.
She's not here?
I received word yesterday that her return from Lyon was to be delayed until this afternoon. Another mystery illness. I just pray for her sake that she returns before the guests arrive.
Your Majesty, I must go. I have urgent
Go? So soon? I was hoping that you'd sit with me and bring some colour into my life. Why are you here, Madame de Chevreuse?
As one of her ladies-in-waiting, your Majesty, it is not uncommon for
You're delivering something to her, aren't you. A gift? A letter? (laughs) I see from your face that it is a letter. From a suitor perhaps? Give it to me.
It is for the Queen's eyes only, your Majesty.
Madame, I demand that you give me that letter.
I cannot.
Your Majesty! (running) Your Majesty, we need you in the ballroom. The cake has arrived.
Not now!
I should go. Goodbye, your Majesty.
No, wait. (frustrated) I'll let you go this time, but I will find out which strutting peacock is trying to make a fool of me, and then he will pay.
Oh, disgusting creature. No wonder the Queen won't go anywhere near him. Well, my Duke, with this letter in my hand and the Queen absent, it leaves you without a fly for your web.
Mmm, Doctor, this is delicious!
Sometimes there's nothing quite like a sticky bun. I could do with a cup of tea, though.
Tea?
Oh, Erimem, you've got so much to experience and discover. I envy you.
I could say the same of you and Peri.
I sometimes think at my age there's nothing left to discover, but something usually turns up. Speaking of Peri, we'd better get back to her.
Nearby water feature.
Ah, peace and quiet at last. Wow, this place is beautiful.
Such beauty. Surely the most beautiful face in all France.
Are you talking to me?
I see nobody else.
No. Look, I think you've got the wrong girl.
Playful today. This is a surprising change, but not unwelcome.
Do we know each other? If you're about to try the weren't we at High School line, trust me, I know you're lying.
You really can be the most enchanting creature.
Now look, I don't know
[OC]: There she is! Forward!
Cardinal's guards.
What?
Sword drawn.
Hey, are you going to
Madame, get behind me.
Not until you explain.
Now!
Hey!
Peri?
Could she have gone back to your Tardis?
Oh, I doubt it. Sensible just isn't in Periâ€™s vocabulary. Let's try down here.
Peri? Peri?
I warn you, gentlemen. You must come through me to get to the lady. En garde.
Hey, I can look after myself.
Sword fight.
You might take this opportunity to run, my lady.
No kidding. What about you?
I shall cover your
Fabric tears. Buckingham cries out. Thud.
Run. Run!
Take her.
Hey! Get your hands off me. Get off me, you creep! Doctor!
You men, what are you doing?
Where did they come from?
Oh, get off! Help!
Stop! Pistol! Down!
Gun shot.
Doctor, all these streets look the same.
Story of my lives. Where is she?
I'm sure she'll be all right.
Yes, I expect you're probably right.
[OC]: Help! Doctor!
On the other hand. Come on!
[OC]: I'm warning you, buster. If you don't put me down, I'll
Gag her. Now move.
Peri makes muffled angry noises, receding. Footsteps approach.
Now where?
Er, I'm not sure. Come on, Peri, give me another sign.
[OC]: (muffled) Help!
There. Come on!
Who are those men?
From the colour of their tunics, I'd say they were Cardinal's Guards. They're making for the street. If they get into crowds, we'll lose them. Ah!
Doctor!
Delmarre, have you no eyes?
I'm dreadfully sorry. Here, let me help you.
Keep your hand. I may have been wounded earlier, but I'm not an invalid.
Come on, Delmarre, it's only a bruised ego.
Of course I didn't mean to suggest. Look, my friend, I don't have time to waste.
You think an apology is a waste? Rouffet, help me up.
I thought you weren't an invalid.
Help me up, you oaf.
He gave you an apology.
Look, we simply don't have time for this right now, so if you don't mind, we'll just be on our way.
I don't think so. Stand fast, sir.
Draws sword.
He wants you to fight him?
Er, yes.
But Peri. They're getting away.
Yes, I know. Gentlemen, I would love to stay and play, but I really have a pressing matter to deal with.
Where's your sword?
Sword? Er, sword. A sword. Metal pointy thing about so long. I don't appear to be carrying one. I once knew a Visigoth who owned one. Terribly nice chap, very misunderstood
He has the demeanour of a Gascony peasant, Delmarre. They aren't known for their swordplay.
Sword drawn.
Here, peasant. Take mine.
Thank you.
Doctor!
Now, sir. Prepare to face the sword of Patrice Delmarre. En garde! Ha!
Oh, dear.
Put up your swords.
Now what?
Could it be?
Cheers from a nearby crowd.
Is our lady finally returning home?
Quickly, gentlemen, sheath. We cannot be seen duelling by her eyes.
What eyes they are, my friend.
Who are they talking about?
I suddenly have a very bad feeling about this.
Doctor, such a magnificent chariot can only be carrying a person of great importance.
If you're a gentleman, which I doubt, you will bow your head as she passes.
As who passes? I. Oh my.
Doctor, in the chariot. It is Peri!
No, Erimem, that's not Peri. In a carriage like that, that can only be one person. Queen Anne.

DELMARRE: Fifty of the Cardinal's guards to one King's Musketeer? Ha, ha! Hardly a challenge, Morand. Besides, that's not the point, is it? The point is, you'd be dead. Ha!
ROUFFET: Delmarre, put the boy down and come have a drink. It's your round.
DELMARRE: Not until I've taught this dog some manners. Oh, I think his friend wants a word.
ROUFFET: What?
DELMARRE: Behind you.
ROUFFET: It's never wise to creep up on a Musketeer. Especially one with the wit, guile, sartorial elegance and charming good looks of Frangois Rouffet. (fight over.) I'll put that bottle on your tab, shall I?
DELMARRE: I must have misheard when you said Queen Anne is nothing more than a common whore who consorts with the Duke of Buckingham. Surely, Captain Morand, you said I may be in the service of Cardinal Richelieu, but my loyalty to the honour of Queen Anne is unswerving. (punch) Then again. (punch)
ROUFFET: Bravo, but your dog is still awake.
DELMARRE: Well, hurry up and finish him. At this rate, the landlord may run out of wine.
ROUFFET: Oh, very well. I say, isn't that the Cardinal running naked through the street?
MORAND: What? Oh! (thud)
DELMARRE: Captain, Captain, I appear to have left my purse in my other cloak. And as my friend has pointed out, it is my round. Now, as your purse is far too full, I shall take twenty pistoles for your ignorance, and twenty more as a lesson in good manners. The Cardinal pays his captains too well, it seems.
ROUFFET: Landlord, more wine.
DELMARRE: (chuckles) The Cardinal pays fat wages these days. Perhaps we should ask for a transfer?
ROUFFET: The red velvet would clash with my Delmarre, look out!
DELMARRE: For God's sake. The Captain still has fight in him. Look at that. My best cloak, ruined.
RICHELIEU: Come now sir, I implore you. Make your move. Strike now or I shall perish from boredom. And I'm sure we both agree that is no way for a warrior to meet his maker.
LOUIS: Your impatience is second only to your insolence. In battle, one must savour the
LOUIS: sweet taste of victory.
RICHELIEU: Tell that to the General who lies bloody on the battlefield with a knife in his back.
LOUIS: Insolence does not become you. Prepare to suffer the consequences of your babbling. Check.
RICHELIEU: Your Majesty, if we concentrated on playing rather than talking, we would finish in half the time.
LOUIS: Indulge me, Richelieu.
RICHELIEU: Very well. Knight takes Bishop. It would appear my life is in your hands.
LOUIS: (laughs) The Crown wipes away the Church.
RICHELIEU: A brave but foolish move. A pawn stands ready, unnoticed in the shadows, waiting to strike. Ha! The Knight is lost.
LOUIS: Your confidence is unfounded. If the Rook should move here
RICHELIEU: The Crown will fall. I believe the phrase I'm looking for is checkmate.
LOUIS: Damn you, Richelieu.
RICHELIEU: Your Majesty, it's just a game.
LOUIS: (sighs) Everything's just a game to you, Cardinal.
DOCTOR: Can we talk about this sensibly, sentient lifeform to sentient lifeform? If this is going to work, you and I are going to have to have some kind of arrangement, aren't we? Now look, I need to get to the navigational controls which are underneath you, so (cat meows) if I could (slash! hiss!) Ow! On the other hand, I'm sure I could probably reprogramme them from the other side of the console. K9, where are you when I really need you.
DOCTOR: Ah, Pharaoh, all set? I hope the wardrobe room had everything you needed?
ERIMEM: Please, Doctor, I no longer need that title. And, as you can see, I have shed the last vestige of my own time.
PERI: Even your hair's growing. You could join the army with a cut like that.
DOCTOR: Yes, well, charming. Absolutely charming. Well done, Peri.
PERI: Maybe I should dump botany and take up fashion. I think I've missed my calling. Want some tips, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Er, no. I'm perfectly happy with this, thank you. I could probably do with a new stick of celery, though.
ERIMEM: (laughs) You are the strangest man I have ever met.
DOCTOR: Hmm. It's a hobby.
ERIMEM: Your Tardis is truly wondrous, Doctor.
PERI: Doctor, couldn't Erimem stay? Just for a while. It would be so cool, travelling with a real live Pharaoh.
ERIMEM: I am no longer Pharaoh, Peri.
DOCTOR: Cool? I'm sorry, it's out of the question, Erimem. I really shouldn't have taken you away from Egypt in the first place.
ERIMEM: You have been more than kind, both of you. I can ask no more. You saved my life.
DOCTOR: Besides, I think you'll be much happier where we're going. Ah, we're landing.
PERI: In the right place, I hope.
DOCTOR: A little faith, please, Peri.
ERIMEM: Why do you make fun of the Doctor?
PERI: (laughs) You've got a lot to learn, Erimem. Aren't you going to check the coordinates?
DOCTOR: No need. I know exactly where we are. The Braxiatel Collection, planetoid KS159. If we're lucky, we should be just in time for dinner.
DOCTOR: Oh, no.
CHEVREUSE: Where is he?
BUCKINGHAM: What is a beautiful lady such as yourself doing in a place like this?
CHEVREUSE: It would appear that I am waiting for my beloved, who is late.
BUCKINGHAM: For which, my dear, I apologise. My work is taking longer than I thought. That plus this wretched damp air has given me a head cold. I wouldn't keep the beautiful Madame de Chevreuse waiting for the entire kingdom. Now here, take this.
CHEVREUSE: A letter? For her.
BUCKINGHAM: Now, now, my dear. You know that you are still my favourite. No one could replace you. But this is necessary.
CHEVREUSE: For the cause?
BUCKINGHAM: Indeed. For the cause.
CHEVREUSE: It's always for the cause.
BUCKINGHAM: But soon this will all be over and my only cause will be you.
CHEVREUSE: And we can be together, my love, without having to hide in the shadows?
BUCKINGHAM: Of course. I shall be proud to display you on my arm. But for now, you have a task ahead of you.
CHEVREUSE: It's only for you that I do this, my Duke. But it must be the last time, do you hear?
BUCKINGHAM: It will be, I promise.
CHEVREUSE: I must fly, then. Take care, my love.
BUCKINGHAM: And you.
BUCKINGHAM: Women. The world is full of women, all of them wretched.
LOUIS: Another game?
RICHELIEU: I would, Sire, but I don't want to miss my cocoa.
LOUIS: Running away like one of your guards, Richelieu?
RICHELIEU: Must we get into this debates about the merits of our personal guards yet again? Can't we talk about the drains instead?
LOUIS: Afraid that you may have to concede that my Musketeers are the noblest breed of soldier in all of France?
RICHELIEU: A noble breed of layabouts and gigolos. How many more reports must I read of skirmishes on the streets? Twelve in the last week alone. You outlaw duelling and they ignore you.
LOUIS: Now what?
SERVANT: Your Majesty, Eminence, Musketeers Delmarre and Rouffet, and Guard Captain Morand.
RICHELIEU: Ah, messengers from the angels to prove my point.
LOUIS: Oh, very well. Have them enter.
SERVANT: Yes, your Majesty.
ROUFFET: (sotto) Stop being such a woman. It's a scratch.
DELMARRE: (sotto) Yes, yes, I know it is, you idiot.
DELMARRE: (sotto) The surgeon tied the bandage too tight, that's all. Anyway, you were supposed to be watching my back.
ROUFFET: (sotto) I can hardly miss it with the weight you've put on.
LOUIS: Gentlemen, I hope you have a good reason to interrupt the important state business of myself and Cardinal Richelieu.
RICHELIEU: Oh please don't feel you need one.
MORAND: I thought I must come immediately to report the action of these miscreants in their unprovoked attack upon your own guards, Eminence.
ROUFFET: Unprovoked! Why, you
DELMARRE: Rouffet!
RICHELIEU: A duel in the throne room. How delightful.
LOUIS: Sheath, gentlemen. Thank you. Would somebody please explain what's going on?
RICHELIEU: Morand?
MORAND: Whilst drinking in the Crown's Courage ale house with Guard Lieutenant Ferraud. You remember him, Eminence. I trained him with my own hands. Unswerving in his loyalty. He was like a son to me.
RICHELIEU: Spare us the tribute, Morand.
MORAND: Yes, of course. We came across Musketeers Delmarre and Rouffet engaged in activities of a sordid nature.
DELMARRE: We were having our breakfast.
MORAND: On seeing the Lieutenant and myself, they set upon us without provocation, killing Ferraud in the process. He bled to death in my arms, Eminence, struck down in the prime of his life by these thugs, his youthful energy ebbing away.
RICHELIEU: Morand, if you don't shut up, I'll have you ebbed away. Your Majesty, even you must see that these men's actions prove their guilt. It strikes me that hours away from the most important social event in the Court's calendar, an event you yourself have claimed will unite this proud nation of ours, it is sad that we, or indeed you, need protection from your own guards. These men must be punished, severely.
LOUIS: I'll be the judge of that, Cardinal. Well, what have you two got to say for yourselves?
ROUFFET: He's lying, your Majesty. They publicly attacked the honour of the Queen. We had to act to defend her.
LOUIS: There you have it. The matter is settled, Cardinal.
RICHELIEU: You're prepared to take their word without a full investigation into the incident?
LOUIS: They're my best men, Cardinal. I trust them. You should do the same. Now, don't you have some money to steal from the poor? Run along now.
RICHELIEU: As I'm sure you have an innocent stag to hunt down in the woods. Morand, attend me.
MORAND: Eminence.
LOUIS: Bravo, gentlemen. Did you see the look on his face?
DELMARRE: Er, yes, Sire.
LOUIS: That'll teach him to blacken the name of my Musketeers. (laughs) For that, my friends, take a sovereign each and celebrate!
ROUFFET: Your Majesty, we couldn't.
LOUIS: I insist. Now, be off with you. I have a ball to prepare for, and I shall expect both of you to be in attendance. And Delmarre, get my personal physician to look at that wound.
DELMARRE: Thank you, Sire. Our compliments to the Queen.
LOUIS: I'll be sure to tell her when she bothers to return home.
DOCTOR: Not exactly what I had in mind. Want to talk about it, old girl? Why seventeenth century France? Oh, I see. You want our guest to stay. Hmm. If I didn't know better, I'd say Peri had put you up to this.
ERIMEM: Who are you talking to, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Er
PERI: Ah, he does it all the time.
PERI: It's quite sweet, really.
DOCTOR: Yes, well.
ERIMEM: Is this really another time?
DOCTOR: Yes. And place. Paris, 1626 to be exact. A good few centuries after your time.
ERIMEM: It's beyond anything I could have imagined.
PERI: You never get used to it. I get goosebumps every time I step out somewhere new. (deep breath) Yuck. Some places smell better than others, though.
DOCTOR: Sewage systems weren't as advanced in this period, Peri, compared to what you're used to.
ERIMEM: Is it safe to look around?
DOCTOR: You should be all right, now that you two have changed, and besides
PERI: Besides what?
DOCTOR: It would be rude not to.
ROUFFET: What a way to work up an appetite. Kill a Cardinal's guard and insult a religious leader.
DELMARRE: Huh, you've always got an appetite, Rouffet. Now, where shall we eat? Planchet's?
ROUFFET: Where else? I wonder how much wine a sovereign will buy? Delmarre, look. Isn't that Madame de Chevreuse? We've not seen her at Court for months.
DELMARRE: I hadn't noticed.
ROUFFET: You're not still pining for her? For heaven's sake, you're not the first. I doubt you'll be the last. Even Morand has seen the inside of her boudoir.
DELMARRE: For someone who asks so many questions, you learn very little.
ROUFFET: I
DELMARRE: Let's eat. At least when you're stuffing your face I can't hear your voice.
DOCTOR: In this period of history, France was undergoing a great deal of social upheaval. Cardinal Richelieu had a vision for uniting the cultural and
PERI: Richelieu? Wasn't he the bad guy?
DOCTOR: Oh, no, no, no, no, no. Quite the opposite. Alexandre Dumas has a lot to answer for. Tiresome man. Completely ignored the notes I gave him on his first draft.
PERI: Hey, where's Erimem?
DOCTOR: Hmm. Ah, I think our friend is making some new discoveries.
ERIMEM: Amazing.
DOCTOR: What is?
ERIMEM: It's incredible. I've never seen anything like it. Why would somebody put glass where a window should be?
DOCTOR: Ah. But when is a window not a window? When it's a jar. Well, I thought it was funny.
ERIMEM: This place is like nothing I have ever seen.
DOCTOR: Come on, you two. Hungry?
PERI: I could eat a horse.
DOCTOR: I wouldn't say that too loudly around here. You may get exactly what you ask for. I thought you were vegetarian?
ERIMEM: Urgh. I'd much rather eat boar.
DOCTOR: We're in the food capital of Europe. I think we can find something a little more adventurous than what you were used to in Thebes. This way.
PERI: Oh!
MAN: You're
PERI: Oh, I'm so sorry. Let me help you.
MAN: Please forgive me. (runs off) I, I didn't
PERI: Hey, come back. I was only helping
DOCTOR: They were frightened of you. How very odd.
PERI: It's weird. Since we arrived, I've had this feeling that everyone's watching me, but when I look round, they look away.
ERIMEM: I was used to that from my people. And you are very attractive, Peri.
PERI: Oh, thanks.
DOCTOR: Hmm. It's interesting, but I really wouldn't worry. Now, perhaps after lunch we should take a stroll down to the Louvre. Of course, it won't become a museum until 1793 and the King is still in residence, but it is the most beautiful building.
PERI: Doctor
DOCTOR: Did I ever tell you I was there when King Philippe Auguste laid the cornerstone to the original back in oh, must have been the twelfth century. I didn't have the heart to tell him that one day it would be desecrated with a giant glass pyramid.
ERIMEM: Pyramid?
PERI: Guys, I'm finding all this fascinating, but er, do you mind if I strike out on my own for a bit? I think you've got more than a willing pupil in Erimem.
DOCTOR: Er, I don't know. I could be dangerous.
PERI: Doctor, after everything we've been through, I think I can handle a morning stroll.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Well, all right. But don't go too far. We'll be just over there.
PERI: Doctor, this is Paris. What could possibly go wrong?
RICHELIEU: Morand, I charge you with keeping peace on the streets, and all you can do is get one of your men killed. Remind me, why do I pay you?
MORAND: Eminence
RICHELIEU: No, no, don't bother. I've already got a headache. While the King continues to arrange tedious social engagements and argue with the Queen, my work will be incomplete. Something must be done.
MORAND: Your men will do whatever you command, Eminence
RICHELIEU: They'd better. The sooner we can. Wait. Driver, stop!
DRIVER: [OC]: Whoa.
MORAND: Eminence? Isn't that?
RICHELIEU: I'm not blind. What is that stupid girl doing alone on the streets? Morand, take two men and follow her, then report straight back to me.
MORAND: Eminence.
MORAND: [OC]: You men, with me.
RICHELIEU: So, my dear. Perhaps we will finally learn the truth. (bangs on roof) Drive on!
CHEVREUSE: Your Majesty. Your Majesty?
LOUIS: : Can I help?
CHEVREUSE: (gasps) Oh Majesty. Your Majesty, you startled me. My heart is racing in my bosom.
LOUIS: Hmm. So I see. My apologies, but I too am surprised to find anyone here. After all, these are the Queen's private gardens.
CHEVREUSE: In that case, Sire, are we both making an indiscretion?
LOUIS: I was taking some air. The palace is in chaos, what with the preparations for tonight's ball. I was just remembering what it was like when these gardens were filled with the Queen's laughter.
CHEVREUSE: She's not here?
LOUIS: I received word yesterday that her return from Lyon was to be delayed until this afternoon. Another mystery illness. I just pray for her sake that she returns before the guests arrive.
CHEVREUSE: Your Majesty, I must go. I have urgent
LOUIS: Go? So soon? I was hoping that you'd sit with me and bring some colour into my life. Why are you here, Madame de Chevreuse?
CHEVREUSE: As one of her ladies-in-waiting, your Majesty, it is not uncommon for
LOUIS: You're delivering something to her, aren't you. A gift? A letter? (laughs) I see from your face that it is a letter. From a suitor perhaps? Give it to me.
CHEVREUSE: It is for the Queen's eyes only, your Majesty.
LOUIS: Madame, I demand that you give me that letter.
CHEVREUSE: I cannot.
SERVANT: Your Majesty! (running) Your Majesty, we need you in the ballroom. The cake has arrived.
LOUIS: Not now!
CHEVREUSE: I should go. Goodbye, your Majesty.
LOUIS: No, wait. (frustrated) I'll let you go this time, but I will find out which strutting peacock is trying to make a fool of me, and then he will pay.
CHEVREUSE: Oh, disgusting creature. No wonder the Queen won't go anywhere near him. Well, my Duke, with this letter in my hand and the Queen absent, it leaves you without a fly for your web.
ERIMEM: Mmm, Doctor, this is delicious!
DOCTOR: Sometimes there's nothing quite like a sticky bun. I could do with a cup of tea, though.
ERIMEM: Tea?
DOCTOR: Oh, Erimem, you've got so much to experience and discover. I envy you.
ERIMEM: I could say the same of you and Peri.
DOCTOR: I sometimes think at my age there's nothing left to discover, but something usually turns up. Speaking of Peri, we'd better get back to her.
PERI: Ah, peace and quiet at last. Wow, this place is beautiful.
BUCKINGHAM: Such beauty. Surely the most beautiful face in all France.
PERI: Are you talking to me?
BUCKINGHAM: I see nobody else.
PERI: No. Look, I think you've got the wrong girl.
BUCKINGHAM: Playful today. This is a surprising change, but not unwelcome.
PERI: Do we know each other? If you're about to try the weren't we at High School line, trust me, I know you're lying.
BUCKINGHAM: You really can be the most enchanting creature.
PERI: Now look, I don't know
MORAND: [OC]: There she is! Forward!
BUCKINGHAM: Cardinal's guards.
PERI: What?
PERI: Hey, are you going to
BUCKINGHAM: Madame, get behind me.
PERI: Not until you explain.
BUCKINGHAM: Now!
PERI: Hey!
DOCTOR: Peri?
ERIMEM: Could she have gone back to your Tardis?
DOCTOR: Oh, I doubt it. Sensible just isn't in Periâ€™s vocabulary. Let's try down here.
ERIMEM: Peri? Peri?
BUCKINGHAM: I warn you, gentlemen. You must come through me to get to the lady. En garde.
PERI: Hey, I can look after myself.
BUCKINGHAM: You might take this opportunity to run, my lady.
PERI: No kidding. What about you?
BUCKINGHAM: I shall cover your
BUCKINGHAM: Run. Run!
MORAND: Take her.
PERI: Hey! Get your hands off me. Get off me, you creep! Doctor!
ROUFFET: You men, what are you doing?
MORAND: Where did they come from?
PERI: Oh, get off! Help!
ROUFFET: Stop! Pistol! Down!
ERIMEM: Doctor, all these streets look the same.
DOCTOR: Story of my lives. Where is she?
ERIMEM: I'm sure she'll be all right.
DOCTOR: Yes, I expect you're probably right.
PERI: [OC]: Help! Doctor!
DOCTOR: On the other hand. Come on!
PERI: [OC]: I'm warning you, buster. If you don't put me down, I'll
MORAND: Gag her. Now move.
ERIMEM: Now where?
DOCTOR: Er, I'm not sure. Come on, Peri, give me another sign.
PERI: [OC]: (muffled) Help!
DOCTOR: There. Come on!
ERIMEM: Who are those men?
DOCTOR: From the colour of their tunics, I'd say they were Cardinal's Guards. They're making for the street. If they get into crowds, we'll lose them. Ah!
ERIMEM: Doctor!
ROUFFET: Delmarre, have you no eyes?
DOCTOR: I'm dreadfully sorry. Here, let me help you.
DELMARRE: Keep your hand. I may have been wounded earlier, but I'm not an invalid.
ROUFFET: Come on, Delmarre, it's only a bruised ego.
DOCTOR: Of course I didn't mean to suggest. Look, my friend, I don't have time to waste.
DELMARRE: You think an apology is a waste? Rouffet, help me up.
ROUFFET: I thought you weren't an invalid.
DELMARRE: Help me up, you oaf.
ERIMEM: He gave you an apology.
DOCTOR: Look, we simply don't have time for this right now, so if you don't mind, we'll just be on our way.
DELMARRE: I don't think so. Stand fast, sir.
ERIMEM: He wants you to fight him?
DOCTOR: Er, yes.
ERIMEM: But Peri. They're getting away.
DOCTOR: Yes, I know. Gentlemen, I would love to stay and play, but I really have a pressing matter to deal with.
DELMARRE: Where's your sword?
DOCTOR: Sword? Er, sword. A sword. Metal pointy thing about so long. I don't appear to be carrying one. I once knew a Visigoth who owned one. Terribly nice chap, very misunderstood
ROUFFET: He has the demeanour of a Gascony peasant, Delmarre. They aren't known for their swordplay.
ROUFFET: Here, peasant. Take mine.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
ERIMEM: Doctor!
DELMARRE: Now, sir. Prepare to face the sword of Patrice Delmarre. En garde! Ha!
DOCTOR: Oh, dear.
ROUFFET: Put up your swords.
DOCTOR: Now what?
DELMARRE: Could it be?
DELMARRE: Is our lady finally returning home?
ROUFFET: Quickly, gentlemen, sheath. We cannot be seen duelling by her eyes.
DELMARRE: What eyes they are, my friend.
ERIMEM: Who are they talking about?
DOCTOR: I suddenly have a very bad feeling about this.
ERIMEM: Doctor, such a magnificent chariot can only be carrying a person of great importance.
DELMARRE: If you're a gentleman, which I doubt, you will bow your head as she passes.
DOCTOR: As who passes? I. Oh my.
ERIMEM: Doctor, in the chariot. It is Peri!
DOCTOR: No, Erimem, that's not Peri. In a carriage like that, that can only be one person. Queen Anne.

elements.text: [Part Two]
Is she still not as beautiful as ever, Delmarre?
A vision. A perfect vision.
The King is the luckiest man in France.
Now, you GascÂ¢on wretch (flourishes sword) prepare to defend yourself.
They've gone!
I have eyes. More than can be said of you. You were supposed to be watching them.
Me? You were the one who insisted on challenging him to a duel just because
you ended up on your backside.
Come on, they can't have gone far.
(breathless) We've lost them.
Yes. Unfortunately, we've also lost Peri.
Why would anyone take Peri?
They haven't. They've taken Queen Anne, or rather, they think they have.
They think they have. What you're saying is that Peri bears a passing resemblance to
More than a passing resemblance.
More than a passing resemblance to this Queen Anne.
Yes. Frustrating, isn't it?
I do not believe in that much coincidence.
Oh, the universe is full of coincidence. Keeps everything ticking along nicely. Shakespeare made a career out of it. Although I'm not sure how that helps us now.
We should go to the Overseer immediately.

Well, you won't find any Overseers in Paris, but you're on the right lines. Come on, Doctor, think. Peri's abductors wore the uniform of the personal guard of Cardinal Richelieu. No, no, no, no, no, that can't be right. Cardinal's guards just don't go around kidnapping Queens.
Should we not seek an audience with this Cardinal?
Probably, but I think we'll find the heart of the problem closer to Queen Anne herself. We need to see the King. Now, I don't meet Louis until, oh, 1637. Hmm, that could complicate things.
Is time travel always this confusing?
Er, yes. Still, I've had a nip and tuck since then, so I'm sure he'll forget. Come on.
To see the King?
Yes, to see the King.
Ah. Going somewhere?
Monsieur Delmarre. Huh. Life's never easy, is it.
Liquid pouring.
Hmm. (sips) Excellent. Yes, truly excellent. I want this for the Earl of Normandy's table. That should keep him happy. The other guests can have the cheap stuff. Now off with you. Shoo.
Yes, your Majesty.
And if we run out this time, I'll have your head.
(distant) Yes, your Majesty.
Door opens, footsteps.
Well, well, well. If it isn't my dear beloved wife.
Louis, please. I'm tired.

I'm just relieved you've seen fit to grace us with your presence. After all, this evening's ball is only the most important engagement of the social calendar. Why should I possibly be worried over my wife's absence?
I'm going to lie down. I need to rest.
It's enough that we've barely shared a meal together over the last six month, but I
will not tolerate you turning your back on me!
If that was all I had to tolerate from you, I'd be the happiest woman alive.
Horse travelling at speed in the streets.
Doctor! Doctor! Help! Hey, watch where you're putting your hands.
How can I convince you that I'm most terribly and sincerely sorry.
By standing and fighting like a true gentleman of honour.
How dare you insult the Doctor! He is the most honourable man I have ever met.
Oh, thank you.
Such loyalty. And spoken by a fine lady.
My name is Erimemushinteperem.
Hmm. And by which tongue-twisting name do you go?
Oh, I'm just the Doctor.
Oh, good. Then you can attend to your wounds once I've finished with you. En garde.
Oh please, can we stop this? Would it help if I said I have to gain an audience with the King on a matter of national security that may even threaten the life of Queen Anne?
I'd say that you were more of a fool than you look. The King is preparing for the State Ball this evening and will see no one, especially a peasant like you.
State Ball?
Another coincidence, Doctor?

I doubt it. A State Ball, you say. Then, gentlemen, it is imperative that I see the King immediately. As two noble, gallant musketeers, I'm sure you already have the favour of His Majesty a dozen times over.
You are correct in that assumption. But you must take me for a fool if you think I'm going to let you just walk straight into the throne room.
You Gascons have no idea about social etiquette, have you?
Doctor, it is obvious these street ruffians are unable to help.
Er
I doubt that the King even knows their names.
I'll have you know we were in the company of the King not half an hour ago.
He gave us a sovereign. He always listens to us.
Then prove it.
Er
Oh, well, that's different. Anything for a lady.
Oh.
Anne, I haven't finished with you.
But I have finished with you. Do you wonder why I didn't want to come back?
But we have to settle this.
Settle what? I'm in no mood to talk, and I'm weary from my journey.
Oh, how very convenient. Just another excuse to go running off to your bed. Or that of your lover.
What are you talking about?
That little harlot, de Chevreuse, paid me a visit today.
How nice for you.
Oh, she didn't expect to see me. No, she had a letter for you. A letter, no doubt, from him.
I have no idea
Don't patronise me! It was from Buckingham, wasn't it? You've seen him again, haven't you? And you're using de Chevreuse to courier your squalid little love letters.
How could I possibly be seeing Buckingham? You banished him from France.
You usually find a way round my rules. You always do. You can't provide me with an heir, and yet you spread yourself around the courts of Europe. I should be rid of you.
The Cardinal would never allow it.
Richelieu is not on the throne, Anne. I think that you forget who holds the real power in France.
Oh, I don't think so.
Don't push me to do something that I might regret.
Too late! We're already married.
Door opens.
Your Majesty, I'm terribly sorry to drop in unannounced.
Door shuts.
We need to talk.
Musketeers! What is the meaning of this?
Remember, Delmarre, this was your idea..
Galloping horses in countryside.
I am not going to tell you again. Get your filthy paws off.
Horse stops.
Hey, watch it. (thud) Ow! Oh! Ow, that hurt. I could have got down myself. Oh, what is this place?
You'll find out soon enough.
Not if I can help it. (thump) See ya, fellas.
Ow! Leave her. She won't get far.
Horse approaching.
Hey! You've gotta help me!
Horse stops.
My dear, this wilderness is no place for a lady of your breeding.
It's you! Oh, we've got to get away from here. Those guys from the city dragged me out here, but I managed to escape.
Ah, you mean those chaps over there.
Come on. We've got to go.
I don't think so, your Majesty.
Your Majesty? Hey, you were wounded, but I can't see
A necessary deception. I had to make it look convincing for the locals.
What? Who are you?
Don't play the innocent. About time, Johnson. Take her Majesty back to the chateau and her up, then get rid of those uniforms.
Yes, your Grace.
Lock me up?
You heard me. Oh, and Anne? Much as I love your playful side, drop that ridiculous voice. It doesn't suit you.
How do you do. I'm the Doctor.
I don't care what you are. You two, what is the meaning of this?
+ ROUFFET: Er, well, Sire, I, it's like this.
Louis, who are these people?
Great heavens. Quite, quite remarkable.
You flatter me.
Whoever you are, I'd ask you to refrain from staring at my wife. Now, I asked you two a question.
Your Majesty. It is such an honour to see you again.
Oh! Er, is it?
Yes, is it?
Surely you haven't forgotten me already? I am the Princess Erimem of Karnak. I was much younger when I first visited your kingdom with my father, but your hospitality has long been remembered.
(laughs) Well, of course I, er, remember you. Who could forget such a striking and regal countenance?
Who indeed?
You honour me, your Majesty. And the invitation to your Ball honours me further.
(sotto) We don't actually have an invitation.)
(sotto) Have faith.
Ah, yes. Of course. (snaps fingers.) You there, footman.
Yes, your Majesty?
Quick, check the seating plan. If she's not on it, put her on it, and be quick about it.
Yes, your Majesty.
Runs off.
And to what do we owe the pleasure of your company before this evening's festivities?
Your Majesty, I
We have come to you on a matter of great urgency. May I present the Doctor, my Royal Vizier and chief advisor.
Dressed like that? I thought he was your jester.
(sotto) Charming. Better than peasant, I suppose. (normal) Ahem. Your Majesties, I have reason to believe that the life of Queen Anne may be in great danger.
As you can see, I stand before you. Where is this danger you speak of?
You see, our friend
My handmaiden, Perpugilliam, was attacked on the streets of your city and abducted. We came straight to you, your Majesty, as the only person in France who could help us.
Oh, very good.
Abducted? A serious crime indeed.
But how does that place my life in danger?
Ah, yes, I was afraid you were going to ask that. This might be a little hard to
believe, but the er Princess's handmaiden bears quite a striking resemblance to your Majesty.
To me?
Yes, it really is quite startling. Two peas in a pod, in fact. I believe the men who abducted Peri mistook her for yourself.
Then we must find these men at once.
That's the other thing.
The men wore the uniform of the Cardinal's guards.
What! Has Richelieu gone mad?
I'm not entirely convinced as to the credentials of these men. Something in their manner, the way they moved, I just can't put my finger on it.
I beg of you, your Majesty. You are our last hope of seeing my handmaiden alive.
Well, since you put it like that. Delmarre? Rouffet? You will go to the Cardinal's palace and escort him here immediately.
Door opens.
Do not trouble yourselves, Musketeers.
Door closes.
I am already here.
Footsteps.
I don't understand why you're doing this. I've never even met you before.
You certainly remembered my name the last time we were together. Always the same with women, they never respect you in the morning.
Now I know you're confusing me with somebody else. Trust me, you're not my type.
Door unlocked.
We'll soon knock that sense of humour out of you. It's not your boudoir back at the palace, but I'm sure you can tart the place up with those cushions.
Wait, you're making a mistake, I'm not
Door closed and locked.
Your Majesty, I had to come here immediately after I received a somewhat distressing report from Captain Morand. I fear the Queen may be in mortal danger.
Everyone but my husband seems to be concerned for my safety today. I am simply overwhelmed.
But I see she stands before me, and looking more beautiful than ever, whilst I stand here looking like a fool. Why is that, do you think, Morand?
Eminence, I did see them.
See who?
Ah, you have a new jester, your Majesty.
Oh please, we don't have time for this. I'm the Doctor, and this is er, Princess Erimem. So glad we sorted that out. Captain Morand, was it? You said you saw
We disturbed a group of men who on first sight would appear to be Cardinal's guards. They were abducting the Queen. It was you, your Majesty, I swear.
And these other guards?
I know the face of every man who serves under his Eminence. These were not Cardinal's guards.
Your story would seem to bear weight, jester. Morand has omitted one, I fear vital, piece of information.
Such as?
The Queen, or whoever the lady might be, was in the company of the Duke of Buckingham.
Buckingham! I knew it! You lied to me, Anne. You have seen him.
If I didn't know he was in Paris, how could I possibly have seen him?
The Duke was wounded, but he disappeared before we could recover our wits. He was seen to be defending the lady from her attackers.
Who's the Duke of Buckingham?
George Villiers, English Prime Minister. Had a thing for the Queen, by all accounts.

And now I have Musketeers practically breaking down the door of my palace. The noise put me off my lunch. On the way here, we passed at least five duels in the streets between our guards. Your Musketeers are after blood, Majesty.
My, my. Word gets around quickly, doesn't it? Hmm, a little too quickly, come to think of it. Interesting.
My Musketeers are defending the honour of their Queen. Would you have them do less, Cardinal?
Please, this will get us nowhere.
You dare to address me in this manner? Princess Erimem, I ask you keep your jester under control.
The Doctor is the only one talking sense.
We must find my handmaiden.

That's the only way we'll find out who's behind this. Somebody has gone to great lengths to stage-manage this kidnap, only Peri has been caught in the middle of it and not the Queen. I don't believe it's coincidence that this happened on the morning of your State Ball.
Oh, very well. Delmarre, Rouffet, let the Princess Erimem have any assistance you can give. I want this mess sorted out before the Ball. We cannot afford any affray tonight.
You can rely on us, your Majesty.
Well, there's a first time for everything, I suppose.
Thank you, your Majesty.
We need information. The kidnappers weren't being what you'd call discreet. Somebody must have seen something.
The word on the street?
Exactly.
Then we know the perfect chap. Somebody who sees everything.
Church bells ringing, street sounds.
Alms for a blind man. Alms for a blind man. Alms for a blind man.
Do you really think this beggar can help us?
If anyone knows what's happening on the streets it's Blind Maurice. He has eyes and ears everywhere.
He used to be called Lame Maurice.
The poor man. What happened?
The bottom fell out of the market.
How very entrepreneurial.
Alms for a blind man. Alms for a
Hello Maurice.
Oh! Oh, you shouldn't creep up on a blind man like that. Nearly gave me an 'eart attack.
Working on your act again?
Monsieur Rouffet, is that you, sir? Oh, it's good to hear your voice. Got any loose change weighing down your purse?
That depends. We need information
I've always got information for the right price, as well you know.
Hmm. Let me introduce you to Princess Erimmm Erim
Just Erimem will do.
Oh, what a beautiful voice, belonging to a beautiful lady I'll wager.
